14/000817 Beslut om avtalsändring för insats FAO FLEGT 2015-2021

description.narrative: This Sida contribution contributes to different levels, i.e. global/normative level [GLOB/NORM], at national/institutional level [NAT/INST] and actors/target group [ACT/TG] of the Theory of Change (ToC) of the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in sustainable economic development 2018-2022. Indeed, it contributes to five of its strategic objectives: 1.1 – Free and equitable trade; 2.1 – Strengthened ownership and tenure rights for land and natural resources; 2.2 – Improved conditions for private sector development, sustainable business and responsible and sustainable investments and innovations; 2.3 – Increased productivity and sustainable production in agriculture, forestry and fisheries, including food security; and 2.4 – Strengthened women's economic empowerment. The target group of the programme, the smallholder forestry farmers, are directly involved in the programme for some of the outcomes (e.g. outcome 3) and indirectly impacted for others (e.g. outcome 4). The FAO FLEGT Programme reports results based on 4 outcomes and selected cross-cutting areas (gender equality and youth). These results also show a connection to GLOBECs objectives, as well as GLOBECs ToC (or how they “channel” change). Results from the FAO FLEGT Programme Example 1 [Outcome 1 – Legal compliance, market access and livelihoods]: In all VPA countries, even where the VPA mechanism itself is stalled as a result of the Covid-19 effects, programme support strengthening the demand for legal timber in the domestic market and MSME compliance along the timber value chain has been instrumental in building opportunities for long-term livelihood generation and sustainable forest resource use. In Cameroon, companies were linked with community forest timber producers and concluded transactions for an approximate 15 000 cubic meters of legal timber [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. In Indonesia, Programme support to private sector associations and NGOs contributed to improved SVLK (Sistem Verifikasi Legalitas Kayu – Timber Legality Assurance System) uptake by supporting legal harvesting, processing and trade by over 400 smallholder timber producers and MSMEs. Support towards alternate timber trading methods, such as the use of e-commerce platforms, has been particularly important for smallholders to ensure business continuity during the pandemic [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. On an outcome level, support through technical assistance and training (such as improved governance systems), empowers that target groups to access local and national markets, fair and equitable trade, improve their livelihoods and thus indirectly contributes to poverty alleviation. This has also allowed the smallholder farmers to better cope with shifting market demands and the impacts of climate change, such as droughts and floods. The result under this outcome reports to several of the tagged objectives under GLOBEC’s strategy, i.e. 1.1, 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 2 [Outcome 1 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Guyana, Programme partners developed training manuals for indigenous communities with guidelines on employment, social security, income tax, forest management and environmental requirements to comply with the Guyana Timber Legality Assurance System (GTLAS) [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This in turn, supports the smallholder forest farmers to build resilience of social-ecological systems and for livelihoods strengthening. This example contributes to objective 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 of GLOBEN’s strategy. Moreover, the examples above elucidates the reader upon the importance of working around institutions’ and organisations’ strengthening, with an emphasis on civil society and collective action, by using an ‘improved livelihoods and sustainable economic development approach’. VPA processes can are often lengthy processes, where the different countries are at different levels of progress towards FLEGT licenses. One of the many main lessons learned, also as emphasised by FLEGT in the ANR, is that during extensive processes, stakeholder can still be kept engaged by supporting the development and roll-out of the building blocks of the VPA. One way of doing this, is to work with institutions’ strengthening and coordination, empowering smallholder forestry farmers in the set up on MSMEs, and by building alliances with likeminded organisations and/or programmes’ such as the Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Example 3 [Outcome 2 – Multi-stakeholder platforms]: In Myanmar, Programme support strengthened the country’s multi-stakeholder FLEGT platform by organizing the first-ever meetings of the 15 State and Regional-level Multi-Stakeholder Groups where 569 stakeholders provided 1,240 suggested activities for inclusion in the FAO-EU FLEGT Work Programme. These were conducted through remote means, representing a significant change in communication and collaboration among stakeholders, successfully demonstrating that remote consultation is possible [NAT/INST] [TG/ ACT]. This positive experience is being used by the Programme to support partners in other countries where there is a need to replicate such remote consultation [GLOB/ NORM]. This example results essentially reports to 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 4 [Outcome 2 – Legal and policy reform and Gender Equality]: In Uganda, the Programme support in 2020 launched a project to develop a gender mainstreaming manual for forest policy to be adopted by the Ugandan Forestry Authorities. This work will create a new approach to engaging women in the forest sector and generating benefits for women, through gender-appropriate material and methods which target women and address their specific needs [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. This result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 5 [Outcome 2 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Peru, lessons learned were gathered from efforts to strengthen the organization and structures for indigenous communities’ forest oversight in two regions (Atalaya and San Martin). It was found that the “Veedurías Forestales” of Peru are most effective when considered a system of implementing community control over their entire territories, rather than specific forest monitoring tools. While these community systems and structures have been well developed on paper, many still show inconsistencies in their operations and are vulnerable to conflict of interests, despite their impartiality and independence from the Government. These lessons learned now enable the Programme to offer concrete recommendations for future strengthening the role of indigenous communities in Peru regarding forest oversight [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. The latest example clearly emphasises on the importance of the presence of the programme in non-VPA countries, critical in capacity building, organisational development, and for creating a momentum around sustainable forest management, legal timber production, market demand, and empowerment of IPLCs. This example reports to objective 2.1 and 2.3 of the strategy. Example 6 – [Gender Equality integration]: The Programme increased efforts in gender mainstreaming. A total of 48 percent of the projects endorsed from the 2019 Calls for Proposal placed a strong emphasis on strengthening gender mainstreaming by including gender as a key component, whilst 30 percent of the projects focusing on MSMEs support included gender components [GLOB/NORM]. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. Since 2017, The Programme has assisted Indonesian CSOs to reinforce Independent Forest Monitoring (IFM) by training and empowering traditionally underrepresented groups such as women and youth. Recognizing this, in 2020, Programme partners provided targeted workshops for more than 78 women across the islands of Java, Sumatra, South Sulawesi and Kalimantan, equipping them with the necessary skills to prepare monitoring plans, conduct IFM and report to relevant authorities [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. As for example 4, this result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 7 [Global contribution of FLEGT-related work to the broader forestry and development agenda]: FAO recognizes that protecting forests is a solution common to multiple development agendas, as part of nature-based solutions to mitigating the effects of climate change, halting deforestation, enabling green growth and preventing further biodiversity loss. For example, in 2020, the Programme contributed to advancing the biodiversity conservation agenda through a series of actions aligned with the Operating Principles of FAO’s Strategy on Mainstreaming Biodiversity Across Agricultural Sectors. By addressing forest degradation caused by illegal logging and overharvesting, the implementation of FLEGT-related interventions promotes Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) through improved law enforcement and governance, thereby protecting forest-dependant livelihoods. SFM is recognized as an important measure to address climate change mitigation and adaptation in agriculture and land-use sectors and comprises a key element of the NDC plans for many countries, as shown in a recent analysis of NDCs in Asia [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. Reported results can be connected to the following strategic objectives: 2.1; 2.2; and 2.3.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Swedish Strategy for global development cooperation on sustainable economic development 2018 – 2022
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar ekonomisk utveckling 2018-2022

description.narrative: General This Conclusion on Performance is based upon FAO FLEGT’s Annual Report 2020 with Annexes, follow-up discussions, peer learning meetings (virtual), and additional reporting materials submitted by the FLEGT team to Sida (upon request). The ANR 2020 submitted by FAO-FLEGT consists in one main report and six annexes, namely: Annex 1: Summary of programme intervention in VPA and non-VPA countries during 2020; Annex 2: Report against programme log-frame indicators; Annex 3: Work plan 2021 Programme-level activities; Annex 4: FAO EU-FLEGT Programme involvement in significant regional/global events related to FLEGT: 2021; Annex 5: Invitation and Agenda for the 18th Steering Committee meeting; Annex 6: Minutes of the 17th Steering Committee Meeting. Objectives of the intervention The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. It is expected that the programme should lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention. Intervention logic for the programme: There are 6 set outcomes and 1 cross-cutting area that is set in order to achieve the set objective of the programme, and these are presented below. Outcome 1: Support for countries engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). VPAs contribute to improved forest sector governance and timber legality on domestic and international markets. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 73 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in VPA countries. In combination with global and regional projects that also primarily addressed VPA countries, 82.4 percent of the budget for projects (20 million USD) has been dedicated to VPA countries. Of these, 108 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 155 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The VPA countries covered by the programme are Cameroon, CAR, Congo, Côte d’Ivoire, DRC, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Thailand, Viet Nam, Guyana and Honduras. Outcome 2: Support for countries not engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). Initiatives that support legal production and consumption of timber and better forest sector governance in countries that are not engaged in the VPA process are strengthened. In other words, this outcome covers progress related to non-VPA countries. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 24 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in non-VPA countries, accounting for 17.6 percent of the budget for projects (4.8 million USD). Of all the projects launched in non-VPA countries to date, 79 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 7 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The non-VPA countries covered by the programme are Colombia, Guatemala, Madagascar, Mozambique, Myanmar, Peru, the Philippines, Benin, Panama and Papua New Guinea. Outcome 3: Private sector support. The capacity of the private sector (particularly MSMEs) to participate in the trade of legal timber has increased. This outcome especially reports on the programmes’ support to private sector development. During the reporting period, the Programme maintained strong support to private sector, primarily targeting MSMEs. Besides building capacity for legality compliance, the Programme supported the uptake of digital tools and platforms demonstrating legal production and facilitating access to legal markets. In 2020, the Programme launched an internal review of Phase III support to MSMEs and gathered preliminary lessons which will provide technical knowledge to scale up support in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Outcome 4: Outreach and knowledge sharing. Stakeholders in both consumer and producer countries demonstrate an improved knowledge of benefits from legal logging, international trade requirements and of best practices for forest law enforcement, governance and trade. Throughout 2020, the Programme supported both country-level communication emerging from projects and programme-level outreach. The Programme also contributed to corporate communication needs emerging from the COVID-19 crisis, namely through the organization of targeted events and the production of thematic policy briefs. Outcome 5: VPA Impact Monitoring. Programme support to VPA impact monitoring has generated results, particularly in Africa and Asia, during the reporting period. One result from this outcome is presented below. Outcome 6: Capacity building and partnerships. In 2020, 35 implementing partners (from VPA and non-VPA countries in all three regions) were requested to undergo the Programme Due Diligence checks, providing more insight into their institutional background, before introducing Programme requirements and receiving training on project management. The process originally applied only to new partners, but has now been extended to all non-governmental actors starting new projects with the Programme, and governmental actors with no prior experience with the Programme. Key area of integration: Gender equality and women’s empowerment in small forest enterprises. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. During Phase III, the Programme has significantly increased the focus on gender equality in forest governance and legal timber value chains, and the significant increase in demand for support to include gender considerations in partner activities since 2019 reflects this trend. There is an additional result area presented in the report, called “Impact of trade and governance”. It is not reported as an outcome, rather integrated throughout the outcomes, but it is possible to track how much of the programmes’ funding that is linked to trade and governance. In 2020, approximately 3% of the total funding went to this result area, and a slight increase compared to 2019 (2%).

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det föreslagna programmet har som målsättning att uppnå en god styrning av skogsbruket i utvecklingsländer samt att främja legal handel med skogsprodukter. Detta förväntas även på lång sikt bidra till en hållbar skogsanvändning och fattigdomsbekämpning. FAO FLEGT är ett stödprogram till EU FLEGT, för att bygga kunskap och kapacitet på policy- såväl som på företags- och samhällsnivå för att länder ska kunna ingå i ”voluntary partnership agreements” (VPA) förhandlingar och/eller för att kunna förbereda och verkställa initiativ för hållbart skogsbruk utanför VPA ramverket. Det är en utveckling av tidigare fas av samma program men med ett större fokus på små och medium-stora företag och deras möjlighet att påverka och delta i förhandlingar om skogslagstiftning och legal handel. Sidas bedömning är att insatsen har potential till att bidra till ett mer hållbart skogsbruk (miljömässigt, socialt och ekonomiskt) och till att de potentiella fördelarna med legal handel av timmer och handelsavtal för ett hållbart skogsbruk även gagnar småbrukare och har potential att hjälpa människor ur fattigdom.
Programmets totala budget är 45,000,000 USD (ca 332,300,000 SEK) av vilket FAO själv kommer att bidra med 10% av Sidas och ECs bidrag. EC har initialt gått in med 13,000,000 EUR men förväntas öka sitt bidrag i takt med att programmet implementeras. Cirka hälften av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas i form av grants genom en direkt stöd mekanism och årliga ”call for proposals” i de aktuella länderna (15 VPA länder och 10 icke-VPA länder).
Initiativet styrs och genomförs av FAO som har stor teknisk kunskap i området samt lång erfarenhet av liknande initiativ till exempel National Forest Program Facility (NFP) och Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Sida stödjer redan FFF initiativet med ett kärnstöd över fem år och FLEGT Facility regionalt (Asien). Det finns goda möjligheter till synergier mellan de tre programmen och Sida, i sin roll som betydande givare till båda, har möjligheten att bidra till utvecklingen mot ett globalt hållbart skogsbruk.

description.narrative: General This Conclusion on Performance is based upon FAO FLEGT’s Annual Report 2020 with Annexes, follow-up discussions, peer learning meetings (virtual), and additional reporting materials submitted by the FLEGT team to Sida (upon request). The ANR 2020 submitted by FAO-FLEGT consists in one main report and six annexes, namely: Annex 1: Summary of programme intervention in VPA and non-VPA countries during 2020; Annex 2: Report against programme log-frame indicators; Annex 3: Work plan 2021 Programme-level activities; Annex 4: FAO EU-FLEGT Programme involvement in significant regional/global events related to FLEGT: 2021; Annex 5: Invitation and Agenda for the 18th Steering Committee meeting; Annex 6: Minutes of the 17th Steering Committee Meeting. Objectives of the intervention The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. It is expected that the programme should lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention. Intervention logic for the programme: There are 6 set outcomes and 1 cross-cutting area that is set in order to achieve the set objective of the programme, and these are presented below. Outcome 1: Support for countries engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). VPAs contribute to improved forest sector governance and timber legality on domestic and international markets. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 73 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in VPA countries. In combination with global and regional projects that also primarily addressed VPA countries, 82.4 percent of the budget for projects (20 million USD) has been dedicated to VPA countries. Of these, 108 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 155 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The VPA countries covered by the programme are Cameroon, CAR, Congo, Côte d’Ivoire, DRC, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Thailand, Viet Nam, Guyana and Honduras. Outcome 2: Support for countries not engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). Initiatives that support legal production and consumption of timber and better forest sector governance in countries that are not engaged in the VPA process are strengthened. In other words, this outcome covers progress related to non-VPA countries. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 24 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in non-VPA countries, accounting for 17.6 percent of the budget for projects (4.8 million USD). Of all the projects launched in non-VPA countries to date, 79 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 7 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The non-VPA countries covered by the programme are Colombia, Guatemala, Madagascar, Mozambique, Myanmar, Peru, the Philippines, Benin, Panama and Papua New Guinea. Outcome 3: Private sector support. The capacity of the private sector (particularly MSMEs) to participate in the trade of legal timber has increased. This outcome especially reports on the programmes’ support to private sector development. During the reporting period, the Programme maintained strong support to private sector, primarily targeting MSMEs. Besides building capacity for legality compliance, the Programme supported the uptake of digital tools and platforms demonstrating legal production and facilitating access to legal markets. In 2020, the Programme launched an internal review of Phase III support to MSMEs and gathered preliminary lessons which will provide technical knowledge to scale up support in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Outcome 4: Outreach and knowledge sharing. Stakeholders in both consumer and producer countries demonstrate an improved knowledge of benefits from legal logging, international trade requirements and of best practices for forest law enforcement, governance and trade. Throughout 2020, the Programme supported both country-level communication emerging from projects and programme-level outreach. The Programme also contributed to corporate communication needs emerging from the COVID-19 crisis, namely through the organization of targeted events and the production of thematic policy briefs. Outcome 5: VPA Impact Monitoring. Programme support to VPA impact monitoring has generated results, particularly in Africa and Asia, during the reporting period. One result from this outcome is presented below. Outcome 6: Capacity building and partnerships. In 2020, 35 implementing partners (from VPA and non-VPA countries in all three regions) were requested to undergo the Programme Due Diligence checks, providing more insight into their institutional background, before introducing Programme requirements and receiving training on project management. The process originally applied only to new partners, but has now been extended to all non-governmental actors starting new projects with the Programme, and governmental actors with no prior experience with the Programme. Key area of integration: Gender equality and women’s empowerment in small forest enterprises. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. During Phase III, the Programme has significantly increased the focus on gender equality in forest governance and legal timber value chains, and the significant increase in demand for support to include gender considerations in partner activities since 2019 reflects this trend. There is an additional result area presented in the report, called “Impact of trade and governance”. It is not reported as an outcome, rather integrated throughout the outcomes, but it is possible to track how much of the programmes’ funding that is linked to trade and governance. In 2020, approximately 3% of the total funding went to this result area, and a slight increase compared to 2019 (2%).

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det föreslagna programmet har som målsättning att uppnå en god styrning av skogsbruket i utvecklingsländer samt att främja legal handel med skogsprodukter. Detta förväntas även på lång sikt bidra till en hållbar skogsanvändning och fattigdomsbekämpning. FAO FLEGT är ett stödprogram till EU FLEGT, för att bygga kunskap och kapacitet på policy- såväl som på företags- och samhällsnivå för att länder ska kunna ingå i ”voluntary partnership agreements” (VPA) förhandlingar och/eller för att kunna förbereda och verkställa initiativ för hållbart skogsbruk utanför VPA ramverket. Det är en utveckling av tidigare fas av samma program men med ett större fokus på små och medium-stora företag och deras möjlighet att påverka och delta i förhandlingar om skogslagstiftning och legal handel. Sidas bedömning är att insatsen har potential till att bidra till ett mer hållbart skogsbruk (miljömässigt, socialt och ekonomiskt) och till att de potentiella fördelarna med legal handel av timmer och handelsavtal för ett hållbart skogsbruk även gagnar småbrukare och har potential att hjälpa människor ur fattigdom.
Programmets totala budget är 45,000,000 USD (ca 332,300,000 SEK) av vilket FAO själv kommer att bidra med 10% av Sidas och ECs bidrag. EC har initialt gått in med 13,000,000 EUR men förväntas öka sitt bidrag i takt med att programmet implementeras. Cirka hälften av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas i form av grants genom en direkt stöd mekanism och årliga ”call for proposals” i de aktuella länderna (15 VPA länder och 10 icke-VPA länder).
Initiativet styrs och genomförs av FAO som har stor teknisk kunskap i området samt lång erfarenhet av liknande initiativ till exempel National Forest Program Facility (NFP) och Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Sida stödjer redan FFF initiativet med ett kärnstöd över fem år och FLEGT Facility regionalt (Asien). Det finns goda möjligheter till synergier mellan de tre programmen och Sida, i sin roll som betydande givare till båda, har möjligheten att bidra till utvecklingen mot ett globalt hållbart skogsbruk.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. The initiative will lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention.

tag.narrative: 12.2 - By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
12.2 - Senast 2030 uppnå en hållbar förvaltning och ett effektivt nyttjande av naturresurser.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

14/000817 Amendment 2 to the Agreement between Sida and FAO FLEGT 2015-2021

description.narrative: This Sida contribution contributes to different levels, i.e. global/normative level [GLOB/NORM], at national/institutional level [NAT/INST] and actors/target group [ACT/TG] of the Theory of Change (ToC) of the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in sustainable economic development 2018-2022. Indeed, it contributes to five of its strategic objectives: 1.1 – Free and equitable trade; 2.1 – Strengthened ownership and tenure rights for land and natural resources; 2.2 – Improved conditions for private sector development, sustainable business and responsible and sustainable investments and innovations; 2.3 – Increased productivity and sustainable production in agriculture, forestry and fisheries, including food security; and 2.4 – Strengthened women's economic empowerment. The target group of the programme, the smallholder forestry farmers, are directly involved in the programme for some of the outcomes (e.g. outcome 3) and indirectly impacted for others (e.g. outcome 4). The FAO FLEGT Programme reports results based on 4 outcomes and selected cross-cutting areas (gender equality and youth). These results also show a connection to GLOBECs objectives, as well as GLOBECs ToC (or how they “channel” change). Results from the FAO FLEGT Programme Example 1 [Outcome 1 – Legal compliance, market access and livelihoods]: In all VPA countries, even where the VPA mechanism itself is stalled as a result of the Covid-19 effects, programme support strengthening the demand for legal timber in the domestic market and MSME compliance along the timber value chain has been instrumental in building opportunities for long-term livelihood generation and sustainable forest resource use. In Cameroon, companies were linked with community forest timber producers and concluded transactions for an approximate 15 000 cubic meters of legal timber [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. In Indonesia, Programme support to private sector associations and NGOs contributed to improved SVLK (Sistem Verifikasi Legalitas Kayu – Timber Legality Assurance System) uptake by supporting legal harvesting, processing and trade by over 400 smallholder timber producers and MSMEs. Support towards alternate timber trading methods, such as the use of e-commerce platforms, has been particularly important for smallholders to ensure business continuity during the pandemic [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. On an outcome level, support through technical assistance and training (such as improved governance systems), empowers that target groups to access local and national markets, fair and equitable trade, improve their livelihoods and thus indirectly contributes to poverty alleviation. This has also allowed the smallholder farmers to better cope with shifting market demands and the impacts of climate change, such as droughts and floods. The result under this outcome reports to several of the tagged objectives under GLOBEC’s strategy, i.e. 1.1, 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 2 [Outcome 1 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Guyana, Programme partners developed training manuals for indigenous communities with guidelines on employment, social security, income tax, forest management and environmental requirements to comply with the Guyana Timber Legality Assurance System (GTLAS) [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This in turn, supports the smallholder forest farmers to build resilience of social-ecological systems and for livelihoods strengthening. This example contributes to objective 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 of GLOBEN’s strategy. Moreover, the examples above elucidates the reader upon the importance of working around institutions’ and organisations’ strengthening, with an emphasis on civil society and collective action, by using an ‘improved livelihoods and sustainable economic development approach’. VPA processes can are often lengthy processes, where the different countries are at different levels of progress towards FLEGT licenses. One of the many main lessons learned, also as emphasised by FLEGT in the ANR, is that during extensive processes, stakeholder can still be kept engaged by supporting the development and roll-out of the building blocks of the VPA. One way of doing this, is to work with institutions’ strengthening and coordination, empowering smallholder forestry farmers in the set up on MSMEs, and by building alliances with likeminded organisations and/or programmes’ such as the Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Example 3 [Outcome 2 – Multi-stakeholder platforms]: In Myanmar, Programme support strengthened the country’s multi-stakeholder FLEGT platform by organizing the first-ever meetings of the 15 State and Regional-level Multi-Stakeholder Groups where 569 stakeholders provided 1,240 suggested activities for inclusion in the FAO-EU FLEGT Work Programme. These were conducted through remote means, representing a significant change in communication and collaboration among stakeholders, successfully demonstrating that remote consultation is possible [NAT/INST] [TG/ ACT]. This positive experience is being used by the Programme to support partners in other countries where there is a need to replicate such remote consultation [GLOB/ NORM]. This example results essentially reports to 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 4 [Outcome 2 – Legal and policy reform and Gender Equality]: In Uganda, the Programme support in 2020 launched a project to develop a gender mainstreaming manual for forest policy to be adopted by the Ugandan Forestry Authorities. This work will create a new approach to engaging women in the forest sector and generating benefits for women, through gender-appropriate material and methods which target women and address their specific needs [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. This result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 5 [Outcome 2 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Peru, lessons learned were gathered from efforts to strengthen the organization and structures for indigenous communities’ forest oversight in two regions (Atalaya and San Martin). It was found that the “Veedurías Forestales” of Peru are most effective when considered a system of implementing community control over their entire territories, rather than specific forest monitoring tools. While these community systems and structures have been well developed on paper, many still show inconsistencies in their operations and are vulnerable to conflict of interests, despite their impartiality and independence from the Government. These lessons learned now enable the Programme to offer concrete recommendations for future strengthening the role of indigenous communities in Peru regarding forest oversight [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. The latest example clearly emphasises on the importance of the presence of the programme in non-VPA countries, critical in capacity building, organisational development, and for creating a momentum around sustainable forest management, legal timber production, market demand, and empowerment of IPLCs. This example reports to objective 2.1 and 2.3 of the strategy. Example 6 – [Gender Equality integration]: The Programme increased efforts in gender mainstreaming. A total of 48 percent of the projects endorsed from the 2019 Calls for Proposal placed a strong emphasis on strengthening gender mainstreaming by including gender as a key component, whilst 30 percent of the projects focusing on MSMEs support included gender components [GLOB/NORM]. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. Since 2017, The Programme has assisted Indonesian CSOs to reinforce Independent Forest Monitoring (IFM) by training and empowering traditionally underrepresented groups such as women and youth. Recognizing this, in 2020, Programme partners provided targeted workshops for more than 78 women across the islands of Java, Sumatra, South Sulawesi and Kalimantan, equipping them with the necessary skills to prepare monitoring plans, conduct IFM and report to relevant authorities [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. As for example 4, this result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 7 [Global contribution of FLEGT-related work to the broader forestry and development agenda]: FAO recognizes that protecting forests is a solution common to multiple development agendas, as part of nature-based solutions to mitigating the effects of climate change, halting deforestation, enabling green growth and preventing further biodiversity loss. For example, in 2020, the Programme contributed to advancing the biodiversity conservation agenda through a series of actions aligned with the Operating Principles of FAO’s Strategy on Mainstreaming Biodiversity Across Agricultural Sectors. By addressing forest degradation caused by illegal logging and overharvesting, the implementation of FLEGT-related interventions promotes Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) through improved law enforcement and governance, thereby protecting forest-dependant livelihoods. SFM is recognized as an important measure to address climate change mitigation and adaptation in agriculture and land-use sectors and comprises a key element of the NDC plans for many countries, as shown in a recent analysis of NDCs in Asia [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. Reported results can be connected to the following strategic objectives: 2.1; 2.2; and 2.3.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Swedish Strategy for global development cooperation on sustainable economic development 2018 – 2022

One of the many main lessons learned, also as emphasised by FLEGT in the ANR, is that during extensive processes, stakeholder can still be kept engaged by supporting the development and roll-out of the building blocks of the VPA. Example 3 [Outcome 2 – Multi-stakeholder platforms]: In Myanmar, Programme support strengthened the country’s multi-stakeholder FLEGT platform by organizing the first-ever meetings of the 15 State and Regional-level Multi-Stakeholder Groups where 569 stakeholders provided 1,240 suggested activities for inclusion in the FAO-EU FLEGT Work Programme. These were conducted through remote means, representing a significant change in communication and collaboration among stakeholders, successfully demonstrating that remote consultation is possible [NAT/INST] [TG/ ACT]. This positive experience is being used by the Programme to support partners in other countries where there is a need to replicate such remote consultation [GLOB/ NORM]. This example results essentially reports to 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 4 [Outcome 2 – Legal and policy reform and Gender Equality]: In Uganda, the Programme support in 2020 launched a project to develop a gender mainstreaming manual for forest policy to be adopted by the Ugandan Forestry Authorities. This work will create a new approach to engaging women in the forest sector and generating benefits for women, through gender-appropriate material and methods which target women and address their specific needs [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. This result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 5 [Outcome 2 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Peru, lessons learned were gathered from efforts to strengthen the organization and structures for indigenous communities’ forest oversight in two regions (Atalaya and San Martin). It was found that the “Veedurías Forestales” of Peru are most effective when considered a system of implementing community control over their entire territories, rather than specific forest monitoring tools. While these community systems and structures have been well developed on paper, many still show inconsistencies in their operations and are vulnerable to conflict of interests, despite their impartiality and independence from the Government. These lessons learned now enable the Programme to offer concrete recommendations for future strengthening the role of indigenous communities in Peru regarding forest oversight [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. The latest example clearly emphasises on the importance of the presence of the programme in non-VPA countries, critical in capacity building, organisational development, and for creating a momentum around sustainable forest management, legal timber production, market demand, and empowerment of IPLCs. This example reports to objective 2.1 and 2.3 of the strategy. Example 6 – [Gender Equality integration]: The Programme increased efforts in gender mainstreaming. A total of 48 percent of the projects endorsed from the 2019 Calls for Proposal placed a strong emphasis on strengthening gender mainstreaming by including gender as a key component, whilst 30 percent of the projects focusing on MSMEs support included gender components [GLOB/NORM]. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. Since 2017, The Programme has assisted Indonesian CSOs to reinforce Independent Forest Monitoring (IFM) by training and empowering traditionally underrepresented groups such as women and youth. Recognizing this, in 2020, Programme partners provided targeted workshops for more than 78 women across the islands of Java, Sumatra, South Sulawesi and Kalimantan, equipping them with the necessary skills to prepare monitoring plans, conduct IFM and report to relevant authorities [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. As for example 4, this result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 7 [Global contribution of FLEGT-related work to the broader forestry and development agenda]: FAO recognizes that protecting forests is a solution common to multiple development agendas, as part of nature-based solutions to mitigating the effects of climate change, halting deforestation, enabling green growth and preventing further biodiversity loss. For example, in 2020, the Programme contributed to advancing the biodiversity conservation agenda through a series of actions aligned with the Operating Principles of FAO’s Strategy on Mainstreaming Biodiversity Across Agricultural Sectors. By addressing forest degradation caused by illegal logging and overharvesting, the implementation of FLEGT-related interventions promotes Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) through improved law enforcement and governance, thereby protecting forest-dependant livelihoods. SFM is recognized as an important measure to address climate change mitigation and adaptation in agriculture and land-use sectors and comprises a key element of the NDC plans for many countries, as shown in a recent analysis of NDCs in Asia [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. Reported results can be connected to the following strategic objectives: 2.1; 2.2; and 2.3.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Swedish Strategy for global development cooperation on sustainable economic development 2018 – 2022
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar ekonomisk utveckling 2018-2022

description.narrative: General This Conclusion on Performance is based upon FAO FLEGT’s Annual Report 2020 with Annexes, follow-up discussions, peer learning meetings (virtual), and additional reporting materials submitted by the FLEGT team to Sida (upon request). The ANR 2020 submitted by FAO-FLEGT consists in one main report and six annexes, namely: Annex 1: Summary of programme intervention in VPA and non-VPA countries during 2020; Annex 2: Report against programme log-frame indicators; Annex 3: Work plan 2021 Programme-level activities; Annex 4: FAO EU-FLEGT Programme involvement in significant regional/global events related to FLEGT: 2021; Annex 5: Invitation and Agenda for the 18th Steering Committee meeting; Annex 6: Minutes of the 17th Steering Committee Meeting. Objectives of the intervention The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. It is expected that the programme should lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention. Intervention logic for the programme: There are 6 set outcomes and 1 cross-cutting area that is set in order to achieve the set objective of the programme, and these are presented below. Outcome 1: Support for countries engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). VPAs contribute to improved forest sector governance and timber legality on domestic and international markets. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 73 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in VPA countries. In combination with global and regional projects that also primarily addressed VPA countries, 82.4 percent of the budget for projects (20 million USD) has been dedicated to VPA countries. Of these, 108 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 155 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The VPA countries covered by the programme are Cameroon, CAR, Congo, Côte d’Ivoire, DRC, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Thailand, Viet Nam, Guyana and Honduras. Outcome 2: Support for countries not engaged in voluntary partnership agreements (VPA). Initiatives that support legal production and consumption of timber and better forest sector governance in countries that are not engaged in the VPA process are strengthened. In other words, this outcome covers progress related to non-VPA countries. Since Phase III began in January 2016, 24 percent of all projects endorsed for funding has been in non-VPA countries, accounting for 17.6 percent of the budget for projects (4.8 million USD). Of all the projects launched in non-VPA countries to date, 79 projects were selected through the Direct Assistance mechanism and 7 through the Call for Proposals mechanism. The non-VPA countries covered by the programme are Colombia, Guatemala, Madagascar, Mozambique, Myanmar, Peru, the Philippines, Benin, Panama and Papua New Guinea. Outcome 3: Private sector support. The capacity of the private sector (particularly MSMEs) to participate in the trade of legal timber has increased. This outcome especially reports on the programmes’ support to private sector development. During the reporting period, the Programme maintained strong support to private sector, primarily targeting MSMEs. Besides building capacity for legality compliance, the Programme supported the uptake of digital tools and platforms demonstrating legal production and facilitating access to legal markets. In 2020, the Programme launched an internal review of Phase III support to MSMEs and gathered preliminary lessons which will provide technical knowledge to scale up support in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Outcome 4: Outreach and knowledge sharing. Stakeholders in both consumer and producer countries demonstrate an improved knowledge of benefits from legal logging, international trade requirements and of best practices for forest law enforcement, governance and trade. Throughout 2020, the Programme supported both country-level communication emerging from projects and programme-level outreach. The Programme also contributed to corporate communication needs emerging from the COVID-19 crisis, namely through the organization of targeted events and the production of thematic policy briefs. Outcome 5: VPA Impact Monitoring. Programme support to VPA impact monitoring has generated results, particularly in Africa and Asia, during the reporting period. One result from this outcome is presented below. Outcome 6: Capacity building and partnerships. In 2020, 35 implementing partners (from VPA and non-VPA countries in all three regions) were requested to undergo the Programme Due Diligence checks, providing more insight into their institutional background, before introducing Programme requirements and receiving training on project management. The process originally applied only to new partners, but has now been extended to all non-governmental actors starting new projects with the Programme, and governmental actors with no prior experience with the Programme. Key area of integration: Gender equality and women’s empowerment in small forest enterprises. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. During Phase III, the Programme has significantly increased the focus on gender equality in forest governance and legal timber value chains, and the significant increase in demand for support to include gender considerations in partner activities since 2019 reflects this trend. There is an additional result area presented in the report, called “Impact of trade and governance”. It is not reported as an outcome, rather integrated throughout the outcomes, but it is possible to track how much of the programmes’ funding that is linked to trade and governance. In 2020, approximately 3% of the total funding went to this result area, and a slight increase compared to 2019 (2%).

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det föreslagna programmet har som målsättning att uppnå en god styrning av skogsbruket i utvecklingsländer samt att främja legal handel med skogsprodukter. Detta förväntas även på lång sikt bidra till en hållbar skogsanvändning och fattigdomsbekämpning. FAO FLEGT är ett stödprogram till EU FLEGT, för att bygga kunskap och kapacitet på policy- såväl som på företags- och samhällsnivå för att länder ska kunna ingå i ”voluntary partnership agreements” (VPA) förhandlingar och/eller för att kunna förbereda och verkställa initiativ för hållbart skogsbruk utanför VPA ramverket. Det är en utveckling av tidigare fas av samma program men med ett större fokus på små och medium-stora företag och deras möjlighet att påverka och delta i förhandlingar om skogslagstiftning och legal handel. Sidas bedömning är att insatsen har potential till att bidra till ett mer hållbart skogsbruk (miljömässigt, socialt och ekonomiskt) och till att de potentiella fördelarna med legal handel av timmer och handelsavtal för ett hållbart skogsbruk även gagnar småbrukare och har potential att hjälpa människor ur fattigdom.
Programmets totala budget är 45,000,000 USD (ca 332,300,000 SEK) av vilket FAO själv kommer att bidra med 10% av Sidas och ECs bidrag. EC har initialt gått in med 13,000,000 EUR men förväntas öka sitt bidrag i takt med att programmet implementeras. Cirka hälften av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas i form av grants genom en direkt stöd mekanism och årliga ”call for proposals” i de aktuella länderna (15 VPA länder och 10 icke-VPA länder).
Initiativet styrs och genomförs av FAO som har stor teknisk kunskap i området samt lång erfarenhet av liknande initiativ till exempel National Forest Program Facility (NFP) och Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Sida stödjer redan FFF initiativet med ett kärnstöd över fem år och FLEGT Facility regionalt (Asien). Det finns goda möjligheter till synergier mellan de tre programmen och Sida, i sin roll som betydande givare till båda, har möjligheten att bidra till utvecklingen mot ett globalt hållbart skogsbruk.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The FLEGT (Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade) initiative aims to exclude illegal timber from the markets, to improve the supply of legal timber and to increase the demand for responsible wood products. The initiative will lead to a positive impact, economic as well as social, in the areas of intervention.

tag.narrative: 12.2 - By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
12.2 - Senast 2030 uppnå en hållbar förvaltning och ett effektivt nyttjande av naturresurser.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

description.narrative: This Sida contribution contributes to different levels, i.e. global/normative level [GLOB/NORM], at national/institutional level [NAT/INST] and actors/target group [ACT/TG] of the Theory of Change (ToC) of the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in sustainable economic development 2018-2022. Indeed, it contributes to five of its strategic objectives: 1.1 – Free and equitable trade; 2.1 – Strengthened ownership and tenure rights for land and natural resources; 2.2 – Improved conditions for private sector development, sustainable business and responsible and sustainable investments and innovations; 2.3 – Increased productivity and sustainable production in agriculture, forestry and fisheries, including food security; and 2.4 – Strengthened women's economic empowerment. The target group of the programme, the smallholder forestry farmers, are directly involved in the programme for some of the outcomes (e.g. outcome 3) and indirectly impacted for others (e.g. outcome 4). The FAO FLEGT Programme reports results based on 4 outcomes and selected cross-cutting areas (gender equality and youth). These results also show a connection to GLOBECs objectives, as well as GLOBECs ToC (or how they “channel” change). Results from the FAO FLEGT Programme Example 1 [Outcome 1 – Legal compliance, market access and livelihoods]: In all VPA countries, even where the VPA mechanism itself is stalled as a result of the Covid-19 effects, programme support strengthening the demand for legal timber in the domestic market and MSME compliance along the timber value chain has been instrumental in building opportunities for long-term livelihood generation and sustainable forest resource use. In Cameroon, companies were linked with community forest timber producers and concluded transactions for an approximate 15 000 cubic meters of legal timber [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. In Indonesia, Programme support to private sector associations and NGOs contributed to improved SVLK (Sistem Verifikasi Legalitas Kayu – Timber Legality Assurance System) uptake by supporting legal harvesting, processing and trade by over 400 smallholder timber producers and MSMEs. Support towards alternate timber trading methods, such as the use of e-commerce platforms, has been particularly important for smallholders to ensure business continuity during the pandemic [NAT/ INST] [TG/ACT]. On an outcome level, support through technical assistance and training (such as improved governance systems), empowers that target groups to access local and national markets, fair and equitable trade, improve their livelihoods and thus indirectly contributes to poverty alleviation. This has also allowed the smallholder farmers to better cope with shifting market demands and the impacts of climate change, such as droughts and floods. The result under this outcome reports to several of the tagged objectives under GLOBEC’s strategy, i.e. 1.1, 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 2 [Outcome 1 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Guyana, Programme partners developed training manuals for indigenous communities with guidelines on employment, social security, income tax, forest management and environmental requirements to comply with the Guyana Timber Legality Assurance System (GTLAS) [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This in turn, supports the smallholder forest farmers to build resilience of social-ecological systems and for livelihoods strengthening. This example contributes to objective 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 of GLOBEN’s strategy. Moreover, the examples above elucidates the reader upon the importance of working around institutions’ and organisations’ strengthening, with an emphasis on civil society and collective action, by using an ‘improved livelihoods and sustainable economic development approach’. VPA processes can are often lengthy processes, where the different countries are at different levels of progress towards FLEGT licenses. One of the many main lessons learned, also as emphasised by FLEGT in the ANR, is that during extensive processes, stakeholder can still be kept engaged by supporting the development and roll-out of the building blocks of the VPA. One way of doing this, is to work with institutions’ strengthening and coordination, empowering smallholder forestry farmers in the set up on MSMEs, and by building alliances with likeminded organisations and/or programmes’ such as the Forest and Farm Facility (FFF). Example 3 [Outcome 2 – Multi-stakeholder platforms]: In Myanmar, Programme support strengthened the country’s multi-stakeholder FLEGT platform by organizing the first-ever meetings of the 15 State and Regional-level Multi-Stakeholder Groups where 569 stakeholders provided 1,240 suggested activities for inclusion in the FAO-EU FLEGT Work Programme. These were conducted through remote means, representing a significant change in communication and collaboration among stakeholders, successfully demonstrating that remote consultation is possible [NAT/INST] [TG/ ACT]. This positive experience is being used by the Programme to support partners in other countries where there is a need to replicate such remote consultation [GLOB/ NORM]. This example results essentially reports to 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. Example 4 [Outcome 2 – Legal and policy reform and Gender Equality]: In Uganda, the Programme support in 2020 launched a project to develop a gender mainstreaming manual for forest policy to be adopted by the Ugandan Forestry Authorities. This work will create a new approach to engaging women in the forest sector and generating benefits for women, through gender-appropriate material and methods which target women and address their specific needs [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. This result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 5 [Outcome 2 – Strengthening the role of communities in forest management]: In Peru, lessons learned were gathered from efforts to strengthen the organization and structures for indigenous communities’ forest oversight in two regions (Atalaya and San Martin). It was found that the “Veedurías Forestales” of Peru are most effective when considered a system of implementing community control over their entire territories, rather than specific forest monitoring tools. While these community systems and structures have been well developed on paper, many still show inconsistencies in their operations and are vulnerable to conflict of interests, despite their impartiality and independence from the Government. These lessons learned now enable the Programme to offer concrete recommendations for future strengthening the role of indigenous communities in Peru regarding forest oversight [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. The latest example clearly emphasises on the importance of the presence of the programme in non-VPA countries, critical in capacity building, organisational development, and for creating a momentum around sustainable forest management, legal timber production, market demand, and empowerment of IPLCs. This example reports to objective 2.1 and 2.3 of the strategy. Example 6 – [Gender Equality integration]: The Programme increased efforts in gender mainstreaming. A total of 48 percent of the projects endorsed from the 2019 Calls for Proposal placed a strong emphasis on strengthening gender mainstreaming by including gender as a key component, whilst 30 percent of the projects focusing on MSMEs support included gender components [GLOB/NORM]. Gender mainstreaming is at the core of numerous initiatives across different countries supported by the Programme. Since 2017, The Programme has assisted Indonesian CSOs to reinforce Independent Forest Monitoring (IFM) by training and empowering traditionally underrepresented groups such as women and youth. Recognizing this, in 2020, Programme partners provided targeted workshops for more than 78 women across the islands of Java, Sumatra, South Sulawesi and Kalimantan, equipping them with the necessary skills to prepare monitoring plans, conduct IFM and report to relevant authorities [NAT/INST] [TG/ACT]. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: 2.1; 2.2; 2.3; and 2.4. As for example 4, this result explicitly reports to the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Example 7 [Global contribution of FLEGT-related work to the broader forestry and development agenda]: FAO recognizes that protecting forests is a solution common to multiple development agendas, as part of nature-based solutions to mitigating the effects of climate change, halting deforestation, enabling green growth and preventing further biodiversity loss. For example, in 2020, the Programme contributed to advancing the biodiversity conservation agenda through a series of actions aligned with the Operating Principles of FAO’s Strategy on Mainstreaming Biodiversity Across Agricultural Sectors. By addressing forest degradation caused by illegal logging and overharvesting, the implementation of FLEGT-related interventions promotes Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) through improved law enforcement and governance, thereby protecting forest-dependant livelihoods. SFM is recognized as an important measure to address climate change mitigation and adaptation in agriculture and land-use sectors and comprises a key element of the NDC plans for many countries, as shown in a recent analysis of NDCs in Asia [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. Reported results can be connected to the following strategic objectives: 2.1; 2.2; and 2.3.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
